SENT.plain: BACKGROUND: An increased incidence of paediatric Crohn's disease was reported recently by our group
AIMS: To assess the incidence and characteristics of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) in northern Stockholm between 1990 and 2001
METHODS: All records of individuals 0-15 years of age with suspected IBD in the population based catchment area of 180000 individuals were scrutinised using defined diagnostic criteria
Patient files were searched for relatives with IBD, and for concomitant autoimmune diseases
RESULTS: A total of 152 children were diagnosed with IBD, corresponding to an overall incidence (per 100000) of IBD of 7.4
The incidence of Crohn's disease (CD) was 4.9, ulcerative colitis (UC) 2.2, and indeterminate colitis 0.2
Between 1990 and 2001, there was a marked increase in the incidence of CD while the incidence of UC was almost unchanged, leading to a net increase in the overall occurrence of IBD
There was a male dominance of CD
Fourteen per cent and 11% of patients with CD and UC, respectively, had a first or second degree relative with IBD
Eighteen per cent and 10% of patients with CD and UC, respectively, had a concomitant autoimmune disease
Ten patients with CD (10%) underwent surgery
CONCLUSIONS: The incidence of CD has increased in northern Stockholm
The current incidence is higher than that reported from other areas
Our results suggest a shift in presentation and diagnosis from UC towards CD, but also a net increase in IBD
Concomitant autoimmune disorders and family history are common in paediatric IBD
